title: 103_hr1927
content:
TRANSFER OF FIREARMS REGULATION FUNCTIONS FROM BUREAU OF ALCOHOL, TOBACCO, AND FIREARMS. The functions related to firearm regulation were transferred from the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, and Firearms to the Attorney General on April 29, 1993. The Attorney General will delegate these functions to the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Contracts, liabilities, records, property, and personnel associated with these functions are also transferred to the Attorney General. Personnel in permanent positions will not be separated or have their grade or compensation reduced due to the transfer under this subsection for a year after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 2. REFERENCES.

References to the Secretary of the Treasury or the Department of the Treasury in relation to the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, and Firearms now refer to the Attorney General and the Department of Justice or the Federal Bureau of Investigation. 

SEC. 3. SAVINGS PROVISIONS. All legal documents issued by various government officials in relation to the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, and Firearms will remain in effect until modified or revoked by authorized officials in accordance with the law. The provisions of this Act do not affect any pending proceedings or applications before the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, and Firearms. Orders issued in such proceedings will continue until modified or revoked by authorized officials or by operation of law. The Act does not impact ongoing proceedings before the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, and Firearms. Orders issued in these proceedings will remain in effect until changed or canceled. Additionally, any suits or actions involving the Bureau or its officers will not be affected by the Act. Under this Act, if an agency or officer is involved in a lawsuit and their functions are transferred to the Attorney General or another Department of Justice official, the suit will continue with the new official substituted or added as a party. The Inspector General Act of 1978 is amended to remove references to specific agencies. Additionally, the requirement of audit by the Comptroller General of the United States is repealed. The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, and Firearms will be renamed within 60 days of the enactment of this Act to reflect the transfer of functions.
